Folks,

I've defined a read only API where links to other resources follow =
an Atom like model and include the media-type & relation as well as the URI=
, so they look something like this in JSON:

links: [ { href: "/foo", type:=
 "fooType", rel: "self" },
         { href: "/bar", type: "barType", rel: "=
http://example.com/customeRel" ]

In a conversation with someone who is not=
 entirely into the whole REST thing they commented

"including the type & r=
elation in the link is extra complexity, if we did it in XML we could just =
figure that out implicitly from the schema when we GET the linked resource"=


Leaving aside XML Vs JSON arguments (which aren't relevant to my question=
) I justified it with an argument that explicitly including the relation me=
ant you didn't need to GET the resource to know what the relationship was (=
as the same type could have different relations to different resources, e.g=
. parent vs child relations) and including the type meant the client could =
know what it was going to GET without actually getting it - e.g. "I don't n=
eed to know about barTypes right now so I won't bother getting them until I=
 need to know about them"

But afterwards I thought to myself while my argu=
ments above seem reasonable there must be other good reasons (that I can't =
immediately think of) for being explicit with types & relations in links in=
 RESTful APIs.

Can you help me with your thoughts on what those other good=
 reasons are?

Thanks
Ben
